text:
Robert Craig "Evel" Knievel was a renowned American stunt performer and entertainer, best known for his daring and death-defying motorcycle jumps and stunts. He was born on October 17, 1938, in Butte, Montana, and grew up with a passion for motorcycles and thrill-seeking.

Knievel began his career as a motorcycle stunt performer in the 1960s, initially performing at local fairs and events. He gained popularity for his high-flying motorcycle jumps, which often featured him soaring over obstacles such as cars, buses, and even the Caesar's Palace fountain in Las Vegas.

Knievel's most famous jump was over the Snake River Canyon in Idaho on September 8, 1974. He attempted to clear the canyon on a rocket-powered motorcycle, but the jump ended in a crash landing, leaving him with severe injuries. Despite the failure, the stunt cemented Knievel's reputation as a daredevil and made him an international celebrity.

Throughout his career, Knievel performed over 75 daredevil stunts and set multiple records for the longest and highest motorcycle jumps. He also appeared on numerous television shows, including "The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson" and "That's Incredible!"

Knievel was known for his flamboyant and charismatic personality, often wearing elaborate costumes and wigs for his performances. He also had a flair for the dramatic, often predicting his own demise before a stunt and then miraculously surviving.

Knievel's stunts and antics were not without controversy, however. He was criticized for the danger and risk he posed to himself and others, and he was involved in several lawsuits and accidents over the years. Despite this, he remained a beloved figure in popular culture, inspiring countless fans and imitators.

Evel Knievel passed away on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, due to complications from diabetes. He left behind a legacy as one of the most iconic and daredevil stunt performers of all time, and his name continues to be synonymous with thrill-seeking and high-stakes entertainment.

Evel Knievel died on November 30, 2007, at the age of 69, due to complications from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
